boardgame.name: The Contagion Chronicle
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The world is ill. You have everything to lose through its sickness.

Loss. Change. Chaos.

Your own blood will rebel against you. Your own herd.

Your own loved ones. Do not believe that just because you’ve had a hundred years on this earth, you’ll be exempt. Just because you were ignorant of it until now does not make you immune. Your waking to the reality of this world — of the great machine in its heart, and the sickness in its veins — is just the first step. You must find others like you and me and make them swear to drive back this Contagion. This world doesn’t have long left. You may be a monster, but perhaps with other monsters, you can drive back the destruction of everything.

The Contagion Chronicle includes:

The first Chronicles of Darkness book to provide guidance on playing creatures of all kinds in a shared story.
Systems and powers enabling teams of vampires, werewolves, mages, Prometheans, changelings, Sin-Eaters, hunters, mummies, Beasts, demons, and Deviants all in the same group, encouraging you to explore all permutations of crossover.
A new mythos — the terrifying Contagion — acting as a catalyst for unifying disparate monsters into allied groups known as the Sworn and the False.
Over ten settings from diverse locations all around the globe, each wracked with its own Contagion, and all waiting to be explored.

boardgame.name: Creatures of Mishna
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb

The Island of Mishna lies in the middle of tractless oceans far to the west of the continent of Khul, and has rarely been visited by explorers or adventurers from more settled and populous lands.

Within this book you will find:


A description of the Island of Mishna
A brief history
A all-new map of the Island
Eighteen ALL NEW creatures to meet
Mishna-specific encounter tables
Treasure Tables


You can also pick up the Paper Minis to bring the monsters directly to your tabletop!

Requires the Advanced Fighting Fantasy 2e Core Rulebook

boardgame.name: Necromancer's Almanac of Animated Skeleton
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Necromancer´s Almanac of Animated Skeletons is an adaption of Almanac of Animated Skeletons for Dark Streets & Darker Secrets.

“Them old bones” have seen so much front line duty in dark fantasy adventures that they often hold no more horror or surprise for the players. 20 different takes, slightly more “tricky” variants are provided in this supplement. 18 of them are adaptions of the aforementioned release, two have been replaced by other entries.

Furthermore, the title includes rules for creating all of these skeletons with the Animate Dead power of DS&DS, as well as an optional table each for backlash and corruption, with a clear focus on necromantic powers.

boardgame.name: Virgins & Vixens
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

At a time in history when women are striving to be seen as equals, it is crucial that we recognize the flaws in our oral traditions and strive to improve how women are portrayed. Virgins & Vixens gives players the opportunity to reshape the women in folklore and create new ideas about how women can behave... maybe saving the day in the process!

Virgins & Vixens Game Information:


Stand alone: You don't need any other game books to play!
All ages: Young children may need help with some of the vocabulary
Designed for Narrator (GM) & 1-4 players but up to 8 can play
Narrative game design encourages creativity and role-play
Short 10 page booklet has a Narrator's Guide, works with text-to-speech, and is searchable on digital devices
8 custom Storybooks (character sheets) included


Players start out as one of 8 classic women archetypes found in folklore, fairy tales and mythology around the world. These archetypes have severe limitations - just like the one-dimensional tropes of women found in these types of stories! Through game-play mechanics like Defiance Rolls and collecting Empowerments, the players break out of these constraints and rewrite the tale of their character!

boardgame.name: Lose Your In-Laws
boardgame.description:
Lose Your In-Laws is a fun card game specially made to test your 'in-law dodging skills'.

The goal is to keep all your in-laws out of your house! If there are three or more in-law cards inside your house, you'll lose the game. But, it gets even worse! If the mother-in-law has entered your house, you'll lose immediately!
So make sure your front door is always closed!

Use 'trouble cards' to open the doors of other players and keep your own door closed with 'action cards'. Get rid of in-laws in front of your door with good 'excuse cards' or send someone away with a 'get out card'.

Are you the last player standing? Can you resist your visiting in-laws? Then you'll win the game!

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Parallel Worlds (Issue 11 - Sep 2020)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Warhammer, Outer Wilds, Rangers of Shadow Deep, Tales from the Loop, original fiction, Writing in the Sand, Frostgrave, mobility in video games, Journeys in Middle-earth, improvising in roleplaying games, Frankenstein
boardgame.rpg: Rangers of Shadow Deep: A Tabletop Adventure Game

boardgame.name: Neon City Shops Encounter Map
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Neon City Shops - RPG Encounter Map
24" x 24" image of a neon lit high street

Files included:

For Large Format Printing
300 DPI JPEG with 1" square grid as part of the image

For Virtual tabletop
140 DPI JPEG with 1" square grid as part of the image

boardgame.name: Hall of the Fire King Encounter Map
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Hall of the Fire King - RPG Encounter Map
36" x 24" image of a great hall with a lava filled chasm (optional square 1" grid).

This map was live drawn during a Virtually UK Games Expo Online seminar - The video of which can be found on the Loke BattleMats Twitch channel.

Files included:

For Large Format Printing
300 DPI JPEG with 1" square grid
300 DPI JPEG with no grid

For Virtual tabletop
72 DPI JPEG with 1" square grid
72 DPI JPEG with no grid

boardgame.name: 100 1990s Era Bystanders
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list contains 100 different innocent (and not so innocent) bystanders that are perfect for adding to your retro rpg campaign. Included in each entry is a first and last name, gender, age, and role/occupation.

boardgame.name: Obelisks of Zarn
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The dreary forested woodlands give way to a large ravine where frigid waters meet after rush down the rocky cliff side meeting a muddy bank full of bones. Thick vines have grown around rocks creating a small bridge to the other side where a path leads towards a small altar. The altar is surrounded by two other small streams and sits at the highest point on the rock it was built on.

Below the altar are five trinkets made from skulls and carved wood corresponding to the four large obelisks that surround the area as well as the shrine itself.

boardgame.name: Desert Oasis
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A desert oasis, or maybe a total mirage! Your party members will be either relieved or really mad at you!

User summary:

An electronic image intended for use as a battlemap.

boardgame.name: Desert Valley
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A sandy valley on the outskirts of a bigger desert.

User summary:

An electronic image intended for use as a battlemap.

boardgame.name: Lava Field
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A basic lava field with those cool hexagonal basalt formations.

User summary:

An electronic image intended for use as a battlemap.

boardgame.name: Mushroom Field
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A big ol' field of big ol' mushrooms!

User summary:

An electronic image intended for use as a battlemap.

boardgame.name: Simple Bridge
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A simple bridge. Sure, you could probably walk through the stream, but then your boots would get all wet and who wants wet boots? Someone went out of their way to build this bridge, you might as well use it!

User summary:

An electronic image intended for use as a battlemap.

boardgame.name: The Cats of UlthaRPG
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

In this one sheet RPG you play as the cats from the classic Lovecraft tale, 'The Cats of Ulthar.' It's super simple mechanics cover character creation, how to play, and cat magic in a way that even a total novice to RPGs can quickly learn.

boardgame.name: Watergate Promoset: 2 gebeurtenissen
Watergate: Cambia la Historia
Watergate: Change in History
Watergate: Die Geschichte gestalten
워터게이트 프로모: 역사에 만약이 있다면
boardgame.description:
Watergate: Change in History is a pair of promo cards for Watergate that was originally given to attendees of the 2020 Camp Capstone virtual convention. Later available as part of Pack C from the Dice Tower 2021 Kickstarter campaign.

One card is for the Nixon player and the other is for the Editor player. If one game of Watergate follows another without the players switching roles, whichever player lost receives their promo card, with that card providing an advantageous action that may be used once at any point in the game.

The two cards are:
The Day After: Move 1 evidence token 2 steps.
Meet the Press: Move the momentum token 2 steps.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: Zeke's Gold Grab!
boardgame.description:
Have you always wanted to stake your claim, strike gold, and spark the next gold rush? Those days may be long gone, but you can capture that same spirit with Zeke’s Gold Grab, Where players take tricks to try and grab the most gold! Join Zeke and his trusty Burro for an adventure in gold country you and your family won’t soon forget.
​
Zeke's Gold Grab is a classic "trick-taking" card game, themed to the Gold Rush of yore, with special cards and unique game play to keep prospectors on their toes.

The object of the game is to win the most gold. Beware of Fool’s Gold, shake things up with an Earthquake, strike it rich with a Gold Rush, or go wild with Burro. But whatever you do, just remember, NOTHING beats the Mother Lode!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: The Monster of Frankenstein
boardgame.description:
From the back of the book:

In 1788, Victor Von Frankenstein became obsessed with the idea of reanimating dead tissue. Victor’s unholy experiments were a success and ultimately, Victor created an unholy abomination that would destroy everything he held dear.

Victor and his monster are certainly the most famous and tragic tale of the Von Frankenstein bloodline, but what of the Von Frankenstein family itself? The chronicles of history portray that the Von Frankenstein bloodline was cursed and damned from it’s inception as far back as the 1st Century A.D., whence Frank Von Frankenstein erected Castle Frankenstein upon the Rock of the Franks and did wage many battles against his greatest enemy, Vlad Tepes.

Inside these vaulted pages you will find the dark and long lost secrets of Victor Von Frankenstein and his creation, the history and legacy of the monster and the Von Frankenstein bloodline.

Complete write ups for twenty six heroes and villains who have encountered the creature or the Von Frankenstein bloodline across the epochs of time.

Three write ups for secret organizations whom have long sought the secrets of the Frankenstein Monster so that they may conquer the world.

boardgame.name: Narrator's Quick Play Guide
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Narrator's Quick Play Guide provides a concise overview of the game's mechanics. It covers skill tests, basic combat, and damage resolution. Despite the game being derived from Dune, there is no setting information in the Quick Play.

While it was intended only as an introduction to the full game, it apparently is the only portion of the game to survive.

boardgame.name: Pulp Era (Original)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Pulp Era originally was published in PDF and HTML format. It was removed as a free, HTML product during the revision that led to the commercial publication of Pulp Era: Cinematic Adventures in the Yesteryear!.

The HTML version was presented as five HTML pages:


Introduction
Character Creation
Character Roles
Game Mechanics & Combat
Might & Magic
boardgame.rpg: Pulp Era: Cinematic Adventures in the Yesteryear!

boardgame.name: Small World of Warcraft: Colored Faction Dice
boardgame.description: Pre-order bonus. Colored Alliance & Horde faction Dice.

listing.notes: New. Shipping is 5 Euros.

Promowürfel Fraktionswürfel (Blau/Rot) Verpackung und Versand 1,- € innerhalb Deutschlands. (Briefpost = unversichert) Verpackung und Versand 3,- € innerhalb Deutschlands. (Päckchen = versichert)
Delivery to Germany only!

boardgame.name: The New Robotech Role-Playing Game
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The New Robotech Role-Playing Game is a fan-created, tabletop implementation of the Robotech setting.

Characters have six Attributes with numeric ratings. The Attributes are Strength, Agility, Coordination, Endurance, Reflexes, and Perception. The game provides several methods of generation, including random roll through points distribution - values run from a low of 2 to a high of 20. Characters also select an Occupation and distribute points into Skills.

The game's combat rules are exceptionally simple and probably insufficient for actual play (generally, combat relies upon Skill use).

A large variety of aircraft, spacecraft, auxiliary, ground vehicles, ground mecha, and air mecha are offered. Detail on each unit ranges from minimal (an illustration) to useable game data.

boardgame.name: The New Marvel-Phile (Issue 41)
boardgame.description: In this month's issue... DOOM!!!

boardgame.name: リアルタイムデコイ (Realtime Decoy)
boardgame.description:
A fully cooperative game for 2-4 players. Non-turn-based, real-time progression! Don't try and rush things, work together aim to win together! With 89 cards and over 60 quests this RPG-style board game can be played over and over again for a long time!

How to win
Players must work together to complete all events.
When a player loses all the lives in their hand, everyone loses and suffers consequences.
If you're in too much of a hurry and have four TEKI cards in your hand, everyone loses and suffers consequences.

How to Play:
The game begins with everyone being dealt four different cards: enemy, life, recovery, and camp. Then deal out the deck to all players. Cards can be played by any player at any time (real-time) to try complete/defeat the events and advance the track token. There is no turn order. Players can also gain skill card to help them in the events.

How the cards work
An enemy card will reduce a decoy's life.
When a camp card is played, players can discuss and choose who is the decoy.
Play two enemy cards and the event progresses.
Save the decoys with a recovery card.

boardgame.name: SAGE
boardgame.description:
User summary:

SAGE was developed as "a very simple generic rules system, with the emphasis very much on the roleplaying". It was intended to be the driving system for at least six settings undergoing contemporaneous development (The Inner Sea Scrolls, Sands of the Mumad, Commune, Forever, The India Tea Company, and Renaissance). The game was published, though the settings apparently were not.

Characters in the game are defined by nine Characteristics divided into three groups of three, namely:

EGO - Determination, Observation, Presence
IQ - Discipline, Intellect, Knowledge
Physique - Agility, Endurance, Strength


Characteristics have a numeric value running from 0 to 4 (1 to 3 are normal), generated by random roll.

Characters select a "Path", which determines physical toughness and some resistances. There are four Paths - Will, Fatigue, Shock, and Wound. Characters also select a Career and a "Life Group", which is essentially a user-defined suite of Skills. Skills are basically narrative tags, not hard definitions.

Action resolution (including combat) uses a relatively simple colored 2d6 roll vs. target number. The roll is read as a pair, yielding a type of "percentage" result; roll "doubles" (11, 22, 33, etc.) have special effects (these are used in "Advanced" rules). Relevant skills provide an add to the first ("10s") die, relevant Characterisitcs are added to the second ("1s") die. Rules for character progression were planned but not developed.

SAGE was published in HTML format. A planned PDF version apparently was not released.

boardgame.name: MetalSkies
boardgame.description:
Do you love epic space battles and cool miniatures? Strategy with a small element of chance thrown in to keep you on your toes? Strive for galactic dominance amongst the stars, in MetalSkies.

Designed for 2-4 players. Set-up time takes less than 10 minutes with a player reaching victory in 1-2 hours. Each player commands their own impressive armada that includes: Battleships, destroyers, bombers, and fighters.

You’ll begin by positioning your fleet strategically across an expansive star map before waging war for limited resources across each star lane. Set-up time takes less than 10 minutes with a player reaching victory in 1-2 hours.

To help you manage your forces, you’ll receive your own fleet card where you can track your ships, their armor, and their payloads. Start things off by framing your strategy around the player action cards you’ve been dealt and the natural advantages the star lanes provide. From there, choose from a variety of game-play tactics that fit your own command style. Sit back and search for valuable scrap, dig in behind flack barriers, or charge forward with your capital ship as you send nukes hurdling towards your enemies. Become a master of these elements, adapt, and survive, for only one can reach ultimate glory!

MetalSkies comes with four complete fleets of WWII-meets-Battlestar Galactica-themed miniatures, action and event cards, fleet management cards, gameplay tokens, multiple star charts, and finally, instructions that you can read in less than 20 minutes.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Victoria Eternal
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Victoria Eternal is a worldbook for an alternative earth, a shadow-world that is both like and not like the one you live in. It is intended to be used with a roleplaying game mechanic, and is being designed and playtested for use with the 'Shadow Bindings' system.

User summary:

Victoria Eternal is published as a compressed archive of linked HTML pages and image files.

boardgame.name: StoryGate Chronicles
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The StoryGate Chronicles uses playing cards for its game rules. Each player needs an ordinary pack of playing cards.
...
Each Suit on the deck represents a different aspect of the character.
Hearts: characters energy, physical skills and combat energy.
Spades: characters endurance, toughness, resilience and stamina.
Diamonds: characters intellect, wits and education.
Clubs: characters charisma, magical potential and ego.

User summary:

Players hold a hand of seven cards which may be played during action resolution. Applicable Skills add to the card value. The modified value is compared to a target number.

boardgame.name: Cyber Protocol
boardgame.description:
Cyber Protocol is an arcade puzzle game set in Cyberpunk scenario with a strong and dynamic gameplay. You impersonate the main hero, whose mission is to bring his Android friend (G0X6) back to life by activating the protocol.

• ABSORBING GAMEPLAY •••••
The team has put every effort to turn each of 100 levels into a new, original challenge, not just with different setups, but also with new traps with different mechanics which could be used in various ways. The plan was that each time you go through a stage, you will get as involved as the first time.

• COMPETITIVE ••••
Share the fun with your family and friends - Cyber Protocol invites up to 4 players to take up the challenge locally! Be careful, only the best hackers can pass it without harm.

• FOR CHALLENGERS ••••
Looking for more adrenaline?
Try hacking the system in the arcade mode at an increased pace and with limited lives. The task is hard, but if you are good enough, you can get your place in the top 20 global ranking of cyber hackers!
Glory, fame and success - it all can be yours!

• FOR RETRO FANS ••••
Miss retro games style?
Don't worry - we got you covered! Throw away your old, dusty console, progress in the game and travel back in time to the 80’s by changing game themes and sounds.

• MUSIC PLAYER ••••
If you want to relax after the hard work of hacking, sit back and listen to the Cyber Protocol’s Synthwave and 8bit soundtracks before going to the next challenge!

(from Nintendo.com website)

boardgame.name: Superpowers RPG
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Superpowers RPG is a world simulation that allows you to play as the leader of a powerful nation. The rest is up to you. The game is played by e-mail.

User summary:

Superpowers RPG was published in HTML and used play-by-email turn resolution. The game was unusual in being entirely free. The HTML rules were supplemented by numerous HTML resources detailing the setting.

boardgame.name: Temple of Caelum
boardgame.description:
Temple of Caelum is a 2-4 player competitive RPG strategy game. Join the quest for ascension and play as both a Hero and Demon Princess to explore the forgotten temple, summon your demonic minions, cast harrowing spells, and battle the primordial Demon King in a final showdown.


Choose from 7 different Heroes to play
Choose from 4 unique Demon Princesses - each with their own deck of 32 spell cards
Summon your demon minions to attack and block your opponents from progressing
Battle the evil Demon King and claim victory!


—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: XRPG Advanced Role Playing Game System
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

This is a role playing game system, a set of rules that forms the structure of a role playing game...A game system is like the laws of nature and physics. It determines the outcome of the player's actions. What would happen if one character tried to strike another or intimidate him? What happens when a character falls off of a building? A gaming system such as this one is used to answer these questions and to do much more. This system is reasonably advanced in use. I designed it to handle any genre or scenario and to do it better than any other game.
boardgame.rpg: XRPG Advanced Role Playing Game System

boardgame.name: VSR: Void Space Racing
boardgame.description:
A fast-paced racing with no friction.

"VSR: Void Space Racing is a one-of-kind racing game that finds itself very welcome in the Switch library. There is simply nothing quite like it; you're wrestling with raw physics as much as your rival racers, and the overall experience is brutal yet incredibly rewarding. Be prepared to swallow your pride in the first few sessions - during which you will be nothing short of a space pinball - and then aim for the stars."
~ Nintendo Life, 8/10

Compete for the highscore online. Unlock new colourful stages by completing single mode races. Challenge a friend in local multiplayer. Drift in space like there's no tomorrow!

Main features:
- No friction
- Online highscores
- Split-screen local multiplayer
- Unlockable spaceships and exciting stages
- Challenging gameplay for racing connoisseurs
- Thrilling electronic soundtrack

(from Nintendo.com website)

boardgame.name: Divided Cities (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
Geteilte Städte (Fan Erweiterung für Carcassonne)
boardgame.description: With this new designed city tiles you can divide cities to keep the majority or make it at least more difficult to take over your city. On the other hand you can use them to invade. ;-)

boardgame.name: Going Under
Guardians of the Deep
Guardians of Treasure
Name This Game
Octopus
Octopussy
Treasures of the Deep
boardgame.description: You have discovered a long-sought-after buried treasure, and just when you thought your troubles were over, things get relly tough! There's a persistent shark who thinks that the treasure belongs to him, and he is after you! As if that were not enough to contend with, there's a big old octopus sitting right above your trove who keeps reaching down to check things out.

boardgame.name: The Coast (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
boardgame.description:
Your influence can be extended to the coasts with new coast tiles, river mouths to the seas.
This expansion is base for several beautiful coast expansions.

boardgame.name: Color Wheel
boardgame.description:
Each player has a "color wheel" card.

6 cards are removed from the deck to create the "degrees pile"

Players, via the Color Wheel card, must choose as quickly as possible the color card they think is closest to the degree.
When all players have drawn their cards, they turn the card over and see who is closest.
The closest player wins the point.
In case of a tie, no one gets a point.

A new round begins.

The player who won the point in the previous round takes the card from the top of the "degrees pile" (it symbolizes his or her point), otherwise it is discarded.

The game ends when the "degrees pile" is empty.

boardgame.name: Big Trouble Adventure 04 - Town by the Sea
boardgame.description:
Publisher Description:
After turning the tide in the battle of Mammoth Park, the heroes are finally leaving the forest and returning home. What they find is a ghost town. The mysterious power has taken over their small coastal town and the one person who can help them return to their normal size is in hiding. How will the heroes handle this new battlefield? Will they get closer to the truth about who the mysterious power is and what they are after?

Town by the Sea is a 7 encounter adventure that includes 4 new monsters, 8 new maps and 2 new puzzles. Select encounters also have double sized maps.

Also includes printer friendly version.

Requires: Big Trouble Settings Guide and Rules

boardgame.name: Historia w działaniu
boardgame.description:
Historia w działaniu ("History in action") is a boardgame for 2-5 players. As members of small associations and foundations you will plan and realize historical projects for local societies.
You will get involved in whole process from planning, getting founds, realizing project and summarizing benefits for societies gained thanks to the project.

The player who will manage to complete most ambitious and accurate projects, wins.

Historia w działaniu is not only a boardgame, but can also inspire by ideas, projects and sources of information shown on cards.

Historia w działaniu was published for Niepodległa fund by Games Development in 2019 and was distributed for historical associations for free.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Seas of Fortune
boardgame.description:
Seas of Fortune is a family game about ships racing around Northern Europe, trying to find the best deals. The players are merchants overseeing each journey their ship makes. They try to guide their ships to the most advantageous cities, and find the best crews to sail them. Each successful unloading of goods in a city earns the player silver, and the game ends on the round someone reaches 100 silver marks.

The game is set in 16th century Europe, and revolves around choosing the best routes for your ship, finding the best crews to get there the fastest, and planning for the future. Loading Cards are revealed to show what products are available in which cities, and Unloading Cards show which cities are buying what products. A further future card of both kinds is also revealed, to show the players what's coming. Old cards go out at the end of a round, and new ones come in instead.

Each round all players choose a new crew for their ship. The first player token rotates over the rounds, and the last player is stuck with the only crew that is left. Each card shows a movement number, and an expertise either in coastal sailing or open sea. However, the choice of crew is not always obvious; the lowest movement number will move first, and the highest moves last. Any ties are solved with the first player token. During a turn, a player can freely move their ship between ports, load it for a fee and unload it for a reward. The faster a ship reaches a port for unloading, the greater the profit will be. The player with the most money when the game ends, wins!

boardgame.name: Misja Kampinos 2: Społeczeństwo
boardgame.description:
Misja Kampinos 2: Społeczeństwo (Mission: Kampinos 2 - Society) is a sequel for the boardgame Misja Kampinos.

It is an easy boardgame published for LGD Kampinos (Between Vistula and Kampinos association). It was distributed for free on autumn 2020.

Players as local citizens influence local government (voivode, mayor, regional council)and develop small projects and investments in their communities, counties and voivodships.

The game consists of action drafting and semicooperative mechanics. It's simple and fast, so you can play it either with your family or friends.

Every card shows a different proposition of an investment, that can be realized in communities of players in real-life. Misja Kampinos 2: Społeczeństwo should be treated not only as a boardgame but also as a source of inspiration for projects, that can change life of clocal citizens.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Corduba 27 a.C.
boardgame.description:
The year is 45 BC. Julius Caesar brings all the leaders of the provinces of Hispania Ulterior together for a meeting in Corduba, where he thanks them for the support received during the recent civil war. The fight between Caesar and Pompey had ended with a clear victor, but not all Roman citizens were completely behind Caesar.

One year later, the cruel governor and Caesar’s right hand man is nearly assassinated as he makes his way to the Basilica. This act turned out to be the precursor to what would happen just two years later. Cneo and Sexto, sons of Caesar’s enemies, taking advantage of the influence that Pompey’s name still carried and capitalizing off the rich resources of the Roman province, took control of all of Hispania, including the colonies of Italica and Corduba. These two traitors had somehow pieced together an army of no less than 13 legions, made up of veterans loyal to Pompey and the remnants of his defeated armies in Africa, along with citizens of Hispania.

Caesar promptly travelled to the capital of Hispania with the intention of crushing the rebellion while it was still in its infancy. After losing a battle to Cneo for control of the bridge, Caesar was forced to winter in Ategua and, as it was necessary to feed his forces, he subsequently pillaged the surrounding area. Many were those who joined the rebellion led by Pompey’s sons, but in the end there weren’t enough of them. Forced to take refuge in the city after the battle of Munda, Caesar besieges Cneo and Sexto. He later takes control of the city after a daring assault on the walls. Sexto manages to escape Caesar’s wrath, but his brother Cneo dies along with another 22,000 citizens of Corduba. As punishment for supporting the rebellion and giving refuge to its instigators, the city is left a smoldering ruin. But from the ashes a new city will arise…

The year is now 27 BC, nearly two decades later, and Augustus, the first emperor, sends representatives of the most influential Roman families to Corduba in order to raise it to its former glory. To achieve this, it will be necessary to rebuild the city and cater to its inhabitants. All of this, of course, under the watchful eye of Rome.
Players, who represent the heirs of different patrician families sent from Rome, will compete for the honor of becoming the next Governor, but must first win the vote of the people, and of Rome.

The game is played out over three eras, each one representing a decade. During a round, players will take actions in turns until all decide to pass. Players use actions to produce or harvest resources, construct buildings and monuments, train legions, and tend to the religious needs of the people. To do this, players will have access to a certain number of specialists and workers that will increase as the city’s population rises.

It is important to note that Corduba is not a tile-laying game, but rather one of building actions that includes familiar worker placement and resource management mechanics.

Actions available at the beginning of the game are scarce and mostly limited to harvesting basic resources in order to construct buildings and train troops. However, as players construct new buildings, the amount of actions available increases, since each building constructed provides a new action. Players will certainly appreciate the sheer number of possible strategies and combinations that arise during the course of a game.

Another of Corduba’s strengths is how a particular game evolves. A total of nine rounds are played, grouped into three decades. At the end of each round, the buildings release their workers and therefore become available for the next round. What this means is that all these buildings, which have been constructed one by one over previous rounds, are now free to all players regardless of who built them. Also, since there is an ever-increasing amount of actions available, strategic possibilities multiply. In addition to this, every action is just as important as the next, which leaves you with the constant feeling that another player has anticipated your move and occupied a building you wanted to activate or built what you wanted to build. Even though the rules do not change from one round to the next, players will quickly realize that the game does, since their strategies and perceptions during the first few rounds will be very different from later ones.
There are no Victory Points in Corduba. In order to win, you will have to garner the favor of the city’s inhabitants and of Rome itself. Constructing buildings in the different districts will improve your reputation there. Providing the largest armies for the Roman Cohorts or giving the largest offering to the gods will also help you win favor in the Senate, as well as, of course, helping the city meet the demands of Rome. At the end of each decade, players will have the opportunity to add to the Senate.

But not all that glitters is gold, and, on occasion, the citizens will rebel. Players will have to deal with these uprisings, but this does not mean they will have to cooperate. However, if this aspect is neglected, the entire city could fall, resulting in a very undesirable outcome – all players lose!
Corduba is a bona fide example of a game with near-infinite strategic possibilities. Each game will play out differently depending on the buildings and monuments constructed, the combinations from families and inheritances that players choose, the demands of Rome, the fluctuation of the resource market, the Res gestae (milestones) available, etc. Even if you try to play in a similar way as you did the last, you will not have the same experience. Truly, no one game of Corduba will be the same – you will uncover different strategies and combinations each time you play.
Corduba is a game of medium to high difficulty with simple rules that anyone can understand, but will profoundly challenge players of even the highest skill levels.

—description from the publisher

This magic items are inspired by the Mexica culture, better known as the Aztec culture in most of the world. As such, they belong in a world of mesmerizing jungles, with cities floating in the middle of a lake, where you can hear the enchanting song of birds that only rivals the color of their feathers. boardgame.name: Oldskull Knights
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Wonderland Imprints is proud to present the second volume in the Mythic World of Oldskull series, providing the advanced modular rules developed for author Kent David Kelly’s epic campaign adventure game. These volumes are designed to integrate perfectly with one another if you collect them all, or to stand alone if you prefer to pick and choose aspects from the Oldskull campaign that you’re personally intrigued by. If you’re looking for universal and directly compatible old school materials to bridge the original game editions created by Arneson and Gygax (1974-1985), Holmes (1977), Moldvay and Cook (1981), Mentzer (1983-1986), and other luminaries of TSR (1974-1989) into a single refined system, you’ve come to the right place.

This second supplement in the series provides a full examination of the labyrinthine rules for cavaliers and paladin-cavaliers, in addition to many other features. You will find six fully realized and refined classes of the knight archetype herein: the chivalric cavalier proper (with fuller, more sympathetic, and fairer rules advocating player free agency), the elven cavalier (complete with stag mounts and bows of course), the drowic cavalier, the paladin (replete with role-playing advice and a detailed coverage of alignment challenges), the anti-paladin Chaos Knight, and the mysterious demon-slaying Knight Templar. All classes have been fully integrated with world mythology, folklore, weird fiction, and detailed campaign notes from the author’s campaign that will bring your knighted characters alive in the World of Oldskull. All of the classes and rules have been reimagined and updated throughout with extensive sagely advice along with out-of-print magazine and newszine errata, supplemented by notes and musings derived from E. Gary Gygax in accordance with his vision for his never-attained Advanced Second Edition.

Twenty-four of the new elements and systems you will find herein include: extensive themes and evocative level titles for all classes; clearer and more internally consistent rules for Yeoman and Noble Cavaliers; a rebalancing of strength of will vs. fear and mind attacks; detailed rules for equine and non-equine mounts (including the Templars’ dungeon-prowling war beasts); parrying rules that make sense; pennon of glory advantages; cavalier henchman and squire details by level; errata-driven rules for weapons of choice; clarified lance usage guidelines; more reasonable systems for exemplary and dishonorable armor; elven and dark elven lore templates; the drowic Riding Lizards of Chthon; a fuller and fairer review of chivalry (it’s not mind control, it’s choice); details for Black Knights; more types of warhorses; more barding; the Chaos Knight class; cultural paladins by mythos; paladin aura of protection errata; better rules for palatine warhorses; disease curing clarifications; a Gygaxian treatise on the meaning and play potential of Lawful Good; the Templar class; twenty unique knightly orders for your campaign; and lots and lots of lore from the World of Oldskull.

This mini-expansion came out of Phase Shift Games' design contest in 2020. Many thanks to the contest winner, Silverlightning, for these excellent ideas!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Festering Crowns
boardgame.description:

A Mists of Akuma adventure for 4–6 PCs of 5th level.

Delve into the eastern fantasy noir steampunk world of Mists of Akuma (original setting book | anniversary edition) with this impressive adventure by the author of Honorable Wills.

The secluded bunki-mura of Byoki is a safe haven for tanuki from the cruelty of Shinko Prefecture but this peace is not without a price—in this case the souls of a wayward group of adventurers. Shortly after a bengoshi orders them to the hidden forest village the PCs awaken in an isolated grove with strange rotting crowns atop their heads, grisly clawed items that refuse to be removed. To save themselves from a terrible fate the party must survive the ritual grounds of a coven of mistwraith witches before finally confronting their duplicitous employer!

The tanuki forest village of Byoki and maps for 8 different encounters and locations.
Yaoguai (CR 7), mistwraith witch (CR 8), dread totem (CR 2), rotcrown cackler (CR 5), tanuki onryo (CR 3), baku (CR 5), tikbalang (CR 9), undead wyvern (CR 8), tanuki guard (CR 1/2), Imperial Rebuilder (CR 9), and of course a smattering of adeddo-oni (hunchlings CR 2, ninja CR 3, samurai CR 5, mage CR 8).
A handout for tracking the curses afflicting each of the adventurers.

A New Look - An article addressing the new look of Bloodlines & Black Magic.

Piercing the Veil - This article discusses some ways to use Pierce the Veil at the game table.

boardgame.name: Dyad
boardgame.description:
A traditional deck trick-taking game that is rare for its use of playing paired cards rather than a single card at a time.
The game uses values 2-7 in a 2 or 3 player game, 2-9 in a 4 player game.

Lead Pairs consist of
A matched pair: Two cards sharing a suit - totaled and requiring others to follow suit.
An unmatched pair: Two cards that have different suits - totaled but not requiring others to follow suit.

Following Pairs consist of

A matched pair: Same as above.

An unmatched pair following an unmatched pair: cards are totaled.

An unmatched pair following a matched pair: the lowest card is considered the total.

A double - An unmatched pair containing a 2, following a matched pair. The higher valued card is doubled.

The highest total takes the trick; the player who takes the trick retrieves an opponent's card played to the trick and leads the next trick.

After a number of tricks (4 in a 3 or 4 player game; 6 in a 2 player game) players total the cards remaining in their hands. This is their score for the round.

At the end of the round in which any player has scored at least 50 points, the highest score wins. If tied, the tied player with the highest score in the last round wins the game.


Dyad plays with a number of variants:

Cipher - (Usually with 3 or 4 players) A player may choose to cipher prior to the start of a phase. If that player takes 0 points, the player scores 20 points.

2's - If a player ends the round with a 2 and any other card, the 2 is subtracted from the score, but having a sole 2 at the end of the round scores 20 points.

Teams - (4 players) Players on a team sit across from one another. Teamed players pass 2 cards to each other prior to the start of the phase. Teams play to score 100 points.

The game generally includes themed decks where themes include new variants.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Hedgemony: A Game of Strategic Choices
boardgame.description:
U.S. defense strategists and policymakers have the perennial challenge of developing capstone documents that can coherently articulate and guide how the U.S. Department of Defense will deliver and maintain combat-credible military forces to deter war and provide national security in alignment with national strategy. These forces must be ready to fight and prevail should deterrence fail against a variety of threats in an evolving and uncertain global security environment, and they must be able to do this with acceptable risks — both in the present against today's threats and in the future against threats that might emerge. Key audiences for these capstone documents include defense planners, programmers, budgeters, managers, analysts, and policymakers who support the development and management of forces that can be postured and employed in alignment with a given defense strategy to accomplish objectives.

Against this backdrop, RAND researchers developed Hedgemony, a wargame designed to teach U.S. defense professionals how different strategies could affect key planning factors in the trade space at the intersection of force development, force management, force posture, and force employment. The game presents players, representing the United States and its key strategic partners and competitors, with a global situation, competing national incentives, constraints, and objectives; a set of military forces with defined capacities and capabilities; and a pool of periodically renewable resources. The players are asked to outline their strategies and are then challenged to make difficult choices by managing the allocation of resources and forces in alignment with their strategies to accomplish their objectives within resource and time constraints.

Hedgemony can be played in a modestly sized conference room equipped with a projection screen and a table big enough for the game board and ten to 12 people. Assuming trained players and facilitators are available, a game session of the length necessary to complete a useful number of turns for the session’s learning objectives will typically require a half-day or full-day commitment. Detailed lists of required game components and full descriptions of the facilities and setup procedures necessary.

This is game is considered a governmental roleplaying game to simulate real world dynamics.

boardgame.name: Tanaeum
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

This guidebook is an overly-ambitious attempt to provide a complete and fully-fleshed depiction of the world of Tanaeum, in order to facilitate campaigns set in that world. Tanaeum is intended as a campaign world for use with the d20 System, and most of the mechanics adhere closely to those of third edition Dungeons & Dragons.
...
The Guidebook is broken up into several sections:


Intro & Reference contains introductory material, such as the page you're reading, as well as suggestions for running adventures in Tanaeum and a handy Glossary of Terms.



The World section contains maps of the great continent Tanaeum and its six major regions. It also contains detailed descriptions of the nations and places of interest within those regions. In addition, a bestiary of creatures native to Tanaeum is included in this section.



Culture contains information about the beliefs and powers of Tanaeum's inhabitants, as well as information on the cosmology and history of the world.



Characters details the various dominant races of Tanaeum and their statistics for use in creating characters. It describes the place of standard Dungeons & Dragons character classes in Tanaeum, as well as several new Prestige Classes unique to this world. An optional segment on using standard D&D races in Tanaeum is also included in this section.



Language covers the various spoken tongues of Tanaeum, with extensive coverage of Hemmedic, the root of most Tanaean languages.



Magic lists the spells, rites and magical artifacts unique to Tanaeum.

boardgame.name: Twilight
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Twilight is a self-published role-playing game developed...over the last four years; its intended purpose is to dominate the world and replace all other RPGs for the betterment of gamers everywhere.
...
It has frequently been said to me that a universal system cannot do everything. Up until recently, I scoffed at such words. However, after testing out a wide variety of games and scenarios, I have come to the conclusion that Twilight can only simulate realistic ideas.
...
In short, Twilight cannot simulate munchkin games.
...
Most games will say something like "bend the rules as you see fit," or "common sense takes precedence over the rules in this book," or "Every rule is an optional rule; some are just more optional than others." This shows us all the vast confidence the writers of such games invest in the fruits of their labor. But my game is different, and so to those who use the rules of Twilight I say this: obey or be cast out.

This game is the epitome of playability and common sense, giving all users both simplicity and realism which other games lack. Its procedures are easy to remember, and easy to follow. Consistent failure to utilize a rule properly is indicative of either boredom or mental lassitude. If afflicted with the former, you should be playing a more interesting scenario; if the latter, you are unfit to be called Master.

User summary:

Despite the author's rather grandiose (perhaps tongue-in-cheek) claims, Twilight is a lightweight, standard implementation of character creation and a simple resolution mechanic. Indeed, the self-promotional aspects of the game are much lengthier than the actual game rules.

Characters are defined by six Attributes (Might, Agility, Logic, Insight, Presence, and Charm). Attributes have a numeric value running from 0 to 6. Values are determined by random roll, modified by character sex. Each Attribute has several dependent Skills. Skills are either "umbrella" or "specific" in scope, and they have a numeric value of 1/2 of their related Attribute's value. The Skill, when used, will have a modifier equal to the Attribute plus the Skill values.

Action resolution uses the Attribute or the Attribute + Skill value, modified by +1d10 (bonus die) and then by -1d10 (penalty die). The result (from -9 to 18) is interpreted by the GM (little guidance is provided). A "Critical Success" is scored on a roll of 6 and 1; a "Critical Failure" is scored on a roll of 1 and 6.

boardgame.name: Party & Co: Extreme 2.0
boardgame.description:
From the same family of Party & Co, Party & Co Extreme is made out of 4 different categories of games: 'Quiz & Co, 'Psyco & Co', 'Show & Co' and 'Art & Co'. Each category have different card games including some like Pictionary, Taboo, Trivial-Pursuit...

People have to compete with each other in teams until they fill out his objective card (a number of games won).

The game includes:
800 cards with different games (200 of each category).
48 'peanuts' (12 of each color)
A pair of party glasses (blind-drawing game) with a color pencil
2 pencils and 2 block notes
1 'flexispaghetti' (shape game)
10 objective cards
1 die and a instructions booklet

boardgame.name: Circles in the Forest (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
boardgame.description:
This expansion brings different features to the forest tiles.
You can can can use them separately or with the origin expansions. The rules of the origin expansion applies so no additional rules are required:

3 tiles with (tree shaped) crop circles,
3 vineyard tiles,
3 hill tiles,
3 bazaar tiles,
3 tiles with flying machine symbol,
3 tiles with mage symbol,
2 tiles with a robber symbol,
4 tiles with wind roses.

boardgame.name: Two Fisted Tales (1st Ed)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Two Fisted Tales is a role playing game which attempts to simulate the fast and outrageous action of the pulp magazines. It uses a simple system for character creation, combining the flexibility of a point system and the convenience of character templates. It also features a very fast, "cinematic," one-roll combat system.

User summary:

The original version of Two Fisted Tales was published in HTML and offered online as a free product. The materials were presented in sixteen main HTML pages ("Chapters") divided into two main sections - "The Hero Book" (character creation) and "The Action Book" (game system). The original materials were removed prior to the commercial publication of the second edition.

boardgame.name: Football Manager 2021
boardgame.description:
FM21 delivers dynamic and fresh true-to-life management experiences that renew the focus on you, the beating heart of your football club. You are equipped with more tools than ever before to develop your managerial prowess and command success at your club. New additions and game upgrades produce unparalleled levels of football authenticity as well as extra layers of depth and drama.

Features and licensing updates will be revealed from early October across our social channels.

Source: The Game Website.
boardgame.videogamehonor: 2020 Global Game Awards Best Management Game of the Year Nominee
2020 Global Game Awards Best Sports Game of the Year Winner

boardgame.name: The Pulp Avengers: Game Mastering Pulp Adventures in the 1930s and 1940s
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Adventure, excitement and danger in the manner of The Shadow, Indiana Jones, Doc Savage and Flash Gordon are the hallmarks of the Pulp RPG genre. While the genre gains its name from the adventure fiction magazines of the 1930s and 1940s, in gaming terms it also includes the hair-raising adventures of the "stay tuned for next week's episode" brand of radio and movie serials. Pulp may even be more correctly described as a meta-genre, as it covers the broad gamut of Horror, SF, Fantasy, Western, Aviation, and many other story genres.

Pulp is not simply a genre or era fixed in stone, it is really a state of mind. Fast-paced and energetic adventures. Exotic locales and two-fisted action. A wistful and nostalgic glimpse of an era that seems familiar but more simpler, innocent and daring. Pulp is all these and more. Some features of the pulp genre include its simple morality of good versus evil, masked and cloaked heroes and heroines, devious villains and their schemes, gun-wielding desperados, cliffhanger endings, weird science, and a world still lush with unexplored places and lost races. Understanding the nostalgic elements of the material the pulps cover and the stylistic conventions used in them are essential in squeezing the most enjoyment out of this rip-snorting and adrenaline-laced gaming genre.

User summary:

The Pulp Avengers: Game Mastering Pulp Adventures in the 1930s and 1940s was an extensive online resource offered to support primarily Two-Fisted Tales, though it is system-agnostic and could be used as a resource for any Pulp game.

Portions of this resource previously were published in The Familiar (Issue 2 - Feb 1995) and The Familiar (Issue 3 - Apr 1995).

boardgame.name: it's KARMA! the board game
boardgame.description:
A chance/strategy roll and move derivative of the ancient reincarnation/morality game of snakes and ladders.

2-6 players compete to reach the finish by negotiating multiple path options, re-direction by special steps and employing non-player pieces to block/unblock paths for self and others.

a play option is included to extend play beyond the finish - as in the original game - such that the player that overshoots the finish returns to the game lower down the board.

3 dice are used.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: El lepe: Juegos autopista
boardgame.description: A racing game where you advance the more words you say from different categories in a given time. Whoever gets to the finish line first wins.

boardgame.name: SINS: The Deck-builder
boardgame.description:
GAME SYSTEM



This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.





SINS is a fantasy card deck-builder with a quick setup and gameplay, filled with a plethora of combos and tough choices throughout the game, in a small package.

To win, gain power, give despair and resolve your dominance.

Components
70 x SINS cards.
20 x Kosmos (starter) cards.
2 x Dominance cards.
5 x rules cards.
3 x misc. cards.

Setup
Each box supports 2 players. Use multiple boxes when playing with more than 2 players.

Deal 10 Kosmos (starter) cards to each player. This is their draw pile, placed in their play area.

Give each player a Dominance card and place it with the Cortadoo logo facing up.

Shuffle all Sins cards together face-down, from the box sets of your choice. Place the cards in the center of the table to form the Realm.

Each player draws a card from the top of the Realm. The highest card-number is the active player (repeat if there is a tie). Destroy these cards. Destroyed cards are placed back in the box.

Then, draw 5 cards from the top of the Realm, into the center of the table, face-up.

All players draw 5 starting cards into their hand from their draw pile (this is their hand limit).

The active player starts the game and takes their first turn.
How to win
When a player reaches two dominance, that player wins the game and the game ends immediately.

You get dominance by resolving opposing despair in the Status phase, and you give despair by attacking your opponents in the Attack phase.

The Dominance card in front of each player has numbers from zero to three. If you’d like to play a longer game, you can optionally play until a player reaches three dominance. For a short (coffee break) game, play for one dominance.

boardgame.name: Virtual Virtual Reality (V3)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Welcome to VVR a new type of role-playing-game with new concepts that allows you to play through a bbs or in live session. In this file you will get to learn how to create a character, get started, and how to play. This file can let you into cyberspace through text, like a text adventure game or if during a live session, through narration.

User summary:

Virtual Virtual Reality is a peculiar "fusion" game, intended to support several styles of play:


As a traditional tabletop game
As a solitaire, procedurally generated game
As an online "text adventure" interactive program
As a setting option for use with The Palladium Role-Playing Game


The game is set in the "future" and envisions a style of multi-user, online virtual reality. Characters, then, are virtual avatars in an online reality. The author suggests that players play "themselves" as their character. The tabletop play method uses a constrained set of options intended to mimic online play.

The game is distributed as a ZIP archive containing several text files:


VVRRULV3 - "User Manual" (character creation)
VVRREFV3 - "Programmers Guide" (fusion of GM guide and actual developer instructions for programmatic implementation)
CYRULES3 - Introduction to Cyberia, the online reality
CYBERIA - Map of Cyberia
VVRMAP - Grid map for procedural play
VRSHEET - Print-and-play character sheet
README - Basic orientation
SETUP - Printing suggestions


The game rules are written in an idiosyncratic style, combining game play rules with implementation details. There is a clear attempt to present the game in a technical way, as if it were a program.

boardgame.name: Stroke & Dagger (Issue 4 - April 1993)
boardgame.description:
Volume 1 Number 4
March/April

Cover by Henry Mayo

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

boardgame.name: Pulp Alley: Burst Templates
boardgame.description:
Includes three premium Pulp Alley Burst Templates -- 3" Burst, Long Burst, and Short Burst.


First Edition has burst type and Pulp Alley logo printed on them.
Second Edition includes reference cards for the templates

boardgame.name: Virtual Virtual Reality (V4)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

There are now other places to goto besides cyberia that are linked via. tunnels placed at various places in the walls of cyberia. These worlds have laws of thier own. The Virtual Excursions places are still there but have the same laws as cyberia. The outer worlds have laws all thier own. These worlds make up whats called The Web. The web is like a giant tinkertoy set where places are joined by lines/ tunnels to other places. Cyberia is still the starting place and center of all activity and the web itself. Most worlds are joined into the outside walls of cyberia at ground level. A few are placed elsewhere.

User summary:

Version IV is released as a "patch" document, in an archive containing all of the files from Virtual Virtual Reality (V3), plus the VVR Version IV" "patch" - intended to replace specific (relatively minor) portions of the rules.

The Version IV archive also includes a dice roller program, a simple character generator program, and support files to implement the game as a "text adventure" on a bulletin board system.

boardgame.name: Until Next Winter
boardgame.description:
Until next winter is a deck-building card game for 2-4 players with both coop and player vs player modes of play. Each game is different, every day offers new suffering. Easy to learn hard to master it is a game that keeps you coming back for more as you try to survive in the woods. Shunned by your village, with only your fellow exiles for company you will have to work together in true cooperation. Depend on each other for help and trust each others skills.

Your crimes are unspoken. The verdict; guilty. Your punishment, exile. You do not know how far from the village you are taken. Deep in the woods in the still hours of an early summer night the hoods are taken off. Dazed and disoriented you are left to your fate. To live or die. With nothing but your fellow condemned to keep you company. As the morning light slowly reveals your new home in shades of grey the deep woods comes alive around you.

You and your fellow exiles must survive as long as you can in the wilderness. Each season you will face increasingly difficult challenges If any player succumbs to perils of the woods all is lost. You live together or you die together.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Pulp Alley: Starter Deck
boardgame.description: Starter deck includes the basic Pulp Alley Fortune Deck plus the 5 basic Reward cards.

boardgame.name: Pulp Alley: Solo Deck
boardgame.description: 40-card Solo Deck is designed to specifically replace the Fortune Deck when you are playing single-player Pulp Alley scenarios.

boardgame.name: i'm sorry did you say street magic
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb:

i'm sorry did you say street magic is a citybuilding storygame, where players collaboratively explore a city that they create together. Each turn, a player adds to the city either a Neighborhood, a Landmark, or a Resident, nesting cards inside of each other to showcase and spotlight the relationship between the city's inhabitants, and the places where they live. These cards are then complicated by Events that take place in the city: festivals, elections, ceremonies, natural disasters, mysteries, or discoveries that change the flow and focus of play. As you play cards, you unearth the city's true names — quirks and qualities that make this place wholly, intrinsically unique.
boardgame.rpgpodcastepisode: 272 – I’m Sorry, Did You Say Street Magic? with Caro Asercion
boardgame.rpg: i'm sorry did you say street magic

boardgame.name: Voyages in Eternity
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

A philosophical allegory can be drawn between free-form gaming and this system, comparing them to religion and science. The basis of free-form is faith: faith in the gamemaster to adjudicate fairly, take all factors into consideration, and maintain the scenario. The basis of Voyages is structure: a structure of theories and procedures, to be utilized by the GM to create the scenario and judge success and failure. And consider this: Religion and Science can be said to strive toward the same goal: an understanding of the universe and our place within it. Likewise, free-form systems and Voyages strive toward a similar pinnacle: to take the mechanics of the system "behind the curtains", allowing players to focus on the scenario and characters without distraction.

User summary:

Voyages in Eternity presents a very complicated system on the assumption that computerized tools will be used to automate all or most of the computational processes.

The final version of the game remains incomplete, with perhaps the most significant missing areas being healing, movement, and a character knowledge system.

boardgame.description:

The 2018 Edition Rewards Pack includes many of previous rewards, updated for clarity and consistency, plus new rewards as well.

boardgame.name: Revenge of the Bird King
boardgame.description:
50% bird, 50% man, 100% ridiculous.

Plant seeds, grow guns, be the bird-man you always wished you could be.

A group of intergalactic super heroes has come to your world, bringing with them a tale of mystery and complete nonsense. Explore, level-up, find secret treasures, and challenge yourself to some good ol' classic jump'n'shoot action in this retro-inspired action/platformer/RPG-lite

(from Nintendo.com website)

boardgame.name: Shield of the Viking
boardgame.description:
Game is Free & Available to PnP. Click on Files to download.


WINNER OF “BEST AREA CONTROL GAME” IN THE 2020 BGG SOLITAIRE GAME DESIGN CONTEST***




Shield of the Viking is a solitaire Tower Defense / Tile placement game that sets you as the Jarl of a small Viking village who is trying to survive the nightly raids from "the riders" who live in the mountains to the north.

The game is played on a board made up of hexagonal spaces that narrow down in quantity from top to bottom. Your objective is to defend your fortress at the bottom of the board just long enough for you to put an end to the raids.

Using 4 colored die each round, the riders path down the mountain and through your village is randomized each turn. The rider will follow the colored pattern of the die rolled through colored arrows on each of the board spaces. The result is a snake like path causing destruction as he moves.

In between Raids, you will have the opportunity to place Viking soldiers and build defensive buildings to stop the Rider before he reaches the bottom. However, you must also decide how many Vikings to keep in the village to defend it vs how many you want to send searching for the rider's home base to defeat them once and for all.

The PnP version was originally designed for the 2020 Solitaire PnP Contest by Joe Fontana

-description from designer

boardgame.name: WeltalMyria
boardgame.description:
Epic Adventures Among the Endless Worlds

From the introduction:

WeltalMyria is a "universal" role playing game-- a universal role playing game with a universe. All of the worlds which the players create and adventure in not only share a common set of rules, they also share a common universe. The WeltanMyr.

The WeltanMyr is made up of an endless array of Spheres, complete worlds, each a separate universe unto itself, which, when viewed from the primal metaspace of the Archepm Al-Mithral appear as great spheres, each as perfect as a pearl. A pearl that, like the oyster, holds within it an entire reality, accessible to those who can reach inside.

The Spheres are in motion within the Archepm Al-Mithral, forming systems among themselves, and even spinning together to form great constellations, the conjunctions of which can last ages, or merely seconds.

The driving force behind this movement, and the creation and destruction of the Spheres, is the Oneiromacht. The Oneiromacht is the extant force of the collective dreams and visions, myths & legends of sentience , called "Man." One of the basic tenets of the Spheres is that sentience is incarnate among all the worlds of the WeltanMyr in the form of "Man." Man is the creature aware of its own existence. Questioning the genesis of that existence, and its purpose, and creating and pursuing forms to explore it. This questing by man is felt as the relentless metaphysical tide of the Oneiromacht, streaming forth from each Sphere to shape and warp the primal matter of the Archepm Al-Mithral

As a star is surrounded by and emits all manner of fields and forces, gravity, electromagnetism, the solar wind, so too does a Sphere. The force of the Oneiromacht burns forth from each Sphere, impacting on the primal reality that is the Archepm Al-Mithral just as the stars we know shape and warp and give light to the space around them. It is this force which drives the eternal dance of the Spheres, their creation & destruction.

All of the worlds of the WeltanMyr are set against this vast, compelling mythos. Within this limitless universe, the players are free to create and adventure in any world, or worlds, they can imagine, whether it be a "flat" world, cut off from the rest of the WeltanMyr by the force of the Oneiromacht, or a system of Spheres, with travel, by way of the Archepm Al-Mithral, possible between them.

The game system supports whatever sort of game the players want, it can be a traditional game, limited to a single world, or elements of the WeltanMyr mythos may be incorporated, allowing a truly epic game, across multiple worlds.
...
WeltalMyria uses the MEGAGE (meh’-gah-gayge) rules system, as its basic "language". This language provides the terms and mechanics necessary to describe the workings of the WeltalMyria universe, and portray the adventures of the characters that inhabit it.

The characteristics of this "game language" are expressed in the rules system’s name of MEGAGE (meh’-gah-gayge).

First, in its pronunciation of (meh’-gah-gayge), the idea of the rules systems ability to provide players a "mega-gage", a single seamless measurement system able to handle anything they might imagine, is expressed.

Second, in the acronym MEGAGE, Multiple Environ & Genre Adventure Game Engine, the thrust of the system, a vast framework for describing worlds and staging adventures, is defined.

There are six basic concepts behind the MEGAGE system.

User summary:

Note the procedure referred to in WeltalMyria as a "Dice Step" is more traditionally referred to as a "Dice Pool".

boardgame.name: Pulp Alley: Horror Deck
boardgame.description:
The optional Horror Deck introduces new and exciting effects for players wanting to add a touch of horror to their Pulp Alley scenarios. Can you survive the mind-rending madness?

The Pulp Alley Horror Deck is made up of 48 cards. There are also included 2 blank Horror cards to make custom cards, replace worn cards, and so on.

Character cards are a great way to record your Pulp Alley characters and leagues, making it fast and easy to switch characters from one scenario to the next. Character cards can also be helpful for clearly indicating which characters have activated (turned sideways) and who is currently down (flipped over).

2 x blank Roster cards

boardgame.name: Laser Kitty Pow Pow
boardgame.description:
Sure, cats are cool. But how about Laser-firing Giant Cat Heads? Unleash the “furry”!

Cute? Maybe.
Fast? Sure.
Wild? You bet!

Laser Kitty Pow Pow is the “purrfect” arcade game for vibrant, fast-paced, and easy to pick-up action.


Team up with a friend in a multiplayer mode exclusive to Nintendo Switch;
Fight more enemies than the highest number you know;
Enjoy explosions and satisfying action;
Unlock, use and upgrade special Cat-laser powers;
Meet Tim the Tailor and craft marvelous Cats;
Progress in an adaptive challenge system and face new enemies at your own pace;
Lose yourself in an over the top retro visual style.


Choose your favorite Kitty and get ready for some serious Pow Pow!

boardgame.name: Super Dungeon Explore: Devil Island
boardgame.description:
Super Dungeon: Explore - Devil Island is a standalone starter set for Super Dungeon: Explore 2nd Edition. It includes a 2nd Edition Rulebook, Hero and Monster Miniatures, Tokens, Loot and Treasure Decks, Super Dungeon Dice, and Dungeon Tiles.

Super Dungeon: Explore is a sword swinging, fireball blasting, monster-mash dungeon crawl! In Super Dungeon: Explore, one player is the Dark Consul who controls all of the dungeon’s monsters; while the remaining players are Heroes bent on stopping the Dark Consul’s evil-doings.

The Devil Island Legends Campaign provides you with a series of linked, narrative adventures featuring the Heroes Momotaro, Saru, Adzuki, and Kiji as they seek to defeat Bomechan and her foul Clan Ijin pirates! The Legends campaign includes quests for your Heroes to accomplish, loot and treasure they can keep from game to game, and dastardly power up cards for the Consul.

This exclusive starter includes a Limited Edition Saru Masterclass Miniature that is only available in this set!

boardgame.name: Dragon Dice (Fourth Edition)
boardgame.description:
GAME SYSTEM



This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.




Players use colorful dice to represent armies of different fantasy species which battle to control essential terrain in this fast-rolling game. Although primarily played as a 2-player game, any number of players can join the struggle. The first player to capture two terrains immediately wins the game, or you may try to obliterate your opponent's dice. Spells and layered strategies benefit certain races as you try to control the odds in this dynamic game full of surprises!

Players build their initial forces based on a point system; 24, 30, 36, and 60 points are common point systems, with most standard constructed tournaments using 36 point army builds. Forces are composed of small (1-point), medium (2-point), and large (3-point) 6-sided units and 10-sided monsters (4-point), with 2 terrain dice representing the terrains being battled over, and a summoning pool with dragons, dragonkin, and minor terrains which can all be summoned into play during battle.

'CHANGES IN FOURTH EDITION'
This game system entry is for the fourth edition of the rules. The game is backwards compatible with all past dice releases except for the King's Die, the first promo die to be retired from the game. Here is a summary of changes from prior versions of the rules.
- Charge and Routing rules have been removed.
- Species abilities have been aligned according to the elements that make up a species and matching it with the elements of the terrain the units are at.
- Death species abilities are now tied to having dead units in the Dead Unit Area (DUA)
- Changes to Species abilities (see current rules for details)
- Revised minor rules. Minors can be brought in if only one element matches the major terrain, and elements present in the minor terrain contribute to species abilities.
- Overhaul of spells and Special Action Icons (SAIs). See the latest spells and SAI reference pages in the rules for new spells and SAI effects.
- New dice have been added such as hybrid dragons and white dragons, new minor terrains, new major terrains, and new species.
- The order of steps in a round has been revised.
- Many force build rules have been removed. There is no longer a limit to the number of magic units or Eldarim Champions allowed in a build.
- Army point costs to include items have been reduced.
- Magic ID doubling has been removed.
- 8th Face bonuses changed to double all ID results (and only ID results.

boardgame.name: The Stygian Society: Stretch Goals
boardgame.description:
This pack includes stretch goals from The Stygian Society Kickstarter.

It includes:


Rita and Delores mid-boss mat
Eigenstein wizard mat
The Seer character mat and 15 character cards
4 Chest cards (Feel Great, Priming the Pump,Feel Good, Back in Action)
3 Upper Treasure Cards (Evil Arrow, Evil Gauntlet, Evil Spellbook)
3 Lower Treasure Cards (Clean Bill of Health, Crypt Keeper, Trap Bypass)
5 Woe Cards (Backstab, Counterattack, Doomed, Starless Night, Stricken Down)
5 Lamentation Cards (Exhaustion, Open Wound, Tired, Unlucky, Xanthous & Sangre)


Woe and Lamentation cards may be added to the game for an even greater challenge. Each hero starts with one Woe or Lamentation that disadvantages them or the party, much like status cards, but much harder to get rid of.

boardgame.name: Worm Jazz
boardgame.description:
What's It About?
Worm Jazz is a wriggly puzzler with a unique blend of game mechanics inspired by classics such as Snake ? and Bomberman ?. You take control of Mr. Mark, an earthworm with a particular fondness for smooth jazz and dapper headwear. Wiggle your way through intricate, mind-bending mazes filled with mines, wormholes and powerups! Are you able to gobble up all the food on each stage and reach the golden apple? ?

A Jam Unlike Any Other
Like jazz, worms are all about mixing things up — Grow by gobbling up all the food on each stage, but watch your diet or you become too long to get into those tight spots! You can eat explosive food ? to blow open closed-off passageways, or create chain reactions with rolling boulders! ?

World Wide Worm
Mark likes to travel ✈️?. Wiggle your way around the world and take on over 50+ challenging scenarios set in vastly different climates, ranging from the arctic north to the arid deserts.

Do It with Style
Progress through the stages and unlock a variety of hats, including the dapper top hat ?, all while jamming it out to smooth jazz tunes - Made especially for wriggling ?

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Mattock
boardgame.description:
In Mattock, you play miners digging corridors through the rock. You can’t dig too closely together though, or the mine will collapse. To win, trap your opponent so they run out of space to mine.

Playing the Game:
On your turn, take these 3 steps in order:

① Mine
Place 1 tile on an open space next to, or connected by other tiles to, at least 1 of your miners. Opponent’s miners block connections.
To prevent the mine from collapsing, the tile must not touch:
• more than 3 other tiles;
• a tile which already touches 3 other tiles.
If you have any miners which were removed on previous turns, place 1 of them on this tile.
If you cannot Mine, you lose the game.

② Move
You may choose to move any 1 of your miners to a tile connected to it. You do not have to move.
You may move through your own miners, but opponent’s miners block your path.

③ Remove
Remove all opponent miners that are now both:
• Not connected to another opponent miner;
• Connected to 2 or more of your miners.
Your opponent takes the removed miner(s) and will place 1 back on the board on their turn.

-description from designer
